p: Since ancient times, consumption of water-extract of B. ligulata has cured urogenital and kidney-stone complaints [ 23, 35, 46, 47]. In Nepal, the rhizome paste of B. ligulata is consumed for treating many diseases including diarrhea, ulcer, dysuria, spleen enlargement, pulmonary infusion, cold, cough, and fever [ 45]. The intestinal worms can also be removed by consuming rhizomes along with molasses (two times/day, 3â€“4 days) [ 38]. The Indians use the dried roots of B. ligulata for treating burns, boils, wounds, and ophthalmia [ 46, 48]. The dried leaf powder of B. pacumbis may be inhaled to bring relief from heavy sneezing [ 49]. In Lahul (Punjab), the locals use B. stratecheyi plants to prepare a poultice, which is applied to heal the joint-stiffness [ 50]. Bergenia species are also used for the treatment of boils and even blisters [ 19].
